results.title: Make-up: aging and hair
results.creator_credit: Tony De Zarraga and Tim Barr
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Beau Hickman, of “Spartacus” and “The Ten commandments” fame, demonstrates basic makeup techniques that easily fall into everyone’s budget. Using a variety of materials, the student learns the techniques of the aging process and the application of beards and moustaches, black eyes, skin tones and built-up noses.

results.title: Acting
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Shows a stage actor during audition and his transition to a motion picture actor. Well known actors including Helen Hayes, Vincent Price, Henry Fonda, Jim Backus, Jean Stapleton, Jeff Corey, Royal Dano, Mariette Hartley, Janet McLachlan and Paul Newman appear and discuss problem areas that a film actor must deal with.

results.title: Filmo 70DR with light meter
results.brief_description:
Leather custom case housing a 16mm Bell and Howell Company film camera, and a Weston Master Universal Exposure Meter with 2 accompanying booklets housed in their original cardboard storage box.

Medium/material description (removed from field for XOS data upgrade)
001: Pentagonal shapped leather fitted case and leather strap with a maroon-coloured velvet interior in good condition.
002: Heavy metal body and two lenses.
003 Plastic and metal.
004: Cardboard lid and base.
005: Paper instruction booklet.
006: Paper instruction booklet.
007: Paper

results.title: Economic Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Film Australia’s Australia”.
Through the sequences in “Economic Australia” students have a rare opportunity to turn back the clock to witness filmmakers’ views of Australia’s economic development. The content focuses on some major events in the economic history of the nation as well as those everyday situations in which economics plays a part in our lives. Presented by Annette Shun Wah.

results.title: Exploring futures
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Film Australia’s Australia”.
This program raises many questions, among them: How might futures compare with the past and present? To what extent can we shape our futures? Is all change necessarily progress? What are some factors supporting and constraining our influence on futures? What kind of future would you prefer? What range of choices are open to individuals groups and governments? Presented by Annette Shun Wah.

results.title: Using the land
results.creator_credit: Judith Adamson, Jan Punch and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Film Australia’s Australia”.
Six themes: OWNING THE LAND, CHANGING THE LAND, FARMING THE LAND, MINING THE LAND, SETTLING THE LAND and APPRECIATING THE LAND. ‘USING THE LAND’ helps to provide answers to four major questions: What is the importance of the land to Australians? How have Australians used the land over time? What are the effects of its usage? What needs to be done to protect and conserve the environment as a sustainable resource for the future? Presented by Annette Shun Wah.

results.title: Rights and responsibilities
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Film Australia’s Australia”.
This program is one of two dealing with politics in Australia during the course of this century. In “Rights and Responsibilities” the film segments have been selected to help students understand the Australian political process. Arranged in four themes, the program illustrates all levels in the political process. There are individuals fighting for their rights, pressure groups, society’s institutions, three levels of government, the monarchy and international relations.. Presented by Annette Shun Wah

results.title: Living together
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Film Australia’s Australia”.
Dealing with changes in the physical, social, cultural, political and economic spheres of Australian life. Each program is made up of short sequences from films and videos stored in the archives of Film Australia. This program looks at the individual and society, discrimination, resolving differences between individuals and groups in our society, working together in groups for a variety of purposes and society in change. Presented by Annette Shun Wah

results.title: Black Australia (A)
results.creator_credit: Darrell Sibosado, Michael Brogan and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Film Australia’s Australia”.
Film and video segments relevant to this topic have been selected with original footage accompanied by original soundtracks. This program represents aspects of Aboriginal culture in Australia, and focuses on Aboriginal identity. The program uses the unifying symbols found in what is now known as the Aboriginal flag. The three colours in the flag symbolise the Aboriginal way of perceiving: red (land and politics), black (identity and self determination), and yellow (art and spirituality). These three interlinked themes are explored in the film with a focus on stimulating deeper understanding by white Australia on Aboriginality, the attitudes of white Australians towards Aboriginal people, racism in Australia, both individual and institutional and the changes needed in attitude and action to achieve justice. Teacher’s Guide included. Presented by Annette Shun Wah. Suitable for upper secondary level.
